Posts.Title: Mets found during planning scan ? marymack2012 marymack2012

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 12:34PM luckypenny wrote: In the wind You don't entirely know the stage , grade etc until they run the pathology on the tumor or tumors.   Your ultrasound or mri give an estimate , but doesn't definitively tell the whole story.  For example, your biopsy may say dcis, but once they do the surgery they may find IDC , or on mri they don't see any nodes inflammed, but then they do the Sentinal node biopsy and several light up .  Or sometimes, they tell you that they estimate the tumor to be 2 cm and then surgery determines its less than that. So the surgery pathology is very important and is what you base treatment decisions on.   They only know about the biopsy sample right now which isn't your final staging or grading.  After surgery, you will meet again with surgeon to go over your pathology and then meet with an oncologist to go over treatment.  What are they saying about your biopsy or mri?  How big do they think the tumor is?  Are they concerned about any nodes?  Have they asked you if you want reconstruction?  Alot of women when they have mastectomy, also have reconstruction at the same time.  I had skin sparing during my mastectomy but didn't do reconstruction at the time, but have the option of doing it later .  My surgeon had no problem doing skin sparing.  Actually , I have decided I don't want reconstruction and would like the extra skin removed, and she said she can do that if I want.  I understand this is all so new and frightening.  I think it would help to sit down with your surgeon again and ask them the questions.  A good surgeon should take the time to answer these and also you need to ask for what you want to be sure the surgeon is a good fit .
Posts.Title: Stage and grade of cancer determined AFTER surgery. What!?! InTheWind InTheWind

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 07:30AM luckypenny wrote: I had 6 nodes positive and 2 more with micromets.  The horse was already out of the barn.  My doctor used adjuvent online to calculate recurrency risk with and without surgery, with and without rads and with surgery, rads , chemo and hormonals.
Posts.Title: Ki-67 score vs. Oncotype neugirl Jewel259

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2013 11:14AM luckypenny wrote: Vered- Did you onc indicate what he would switch you to if you stopped taxol?  Some people who don't do well on taxol switch to taxotere.  I guess if it were me , I would want the onc to lay out the risks and benefits to me in terms of continuing taxol, starting a different med, or stopping all together.  When I had taxol, I had a bad reaction to the first one, fever, bad body aches, ( couldn't get out of bed etc).  The 2nd, 3rd and 4th, caused lower back ache, and numb toes and facial neuropathy.  I also had a cough and congestion and hoarseness on it too. Two of my friends had the same symptoms as me.  I had Dose Dense and one had 12 weekly.   I am happy to say that I do not have any of those symptoms now and they cleared up after treatment.  But there weren't fun! I am not very good at analyzing studies, what is the gist of the study that you are posting?  I am certainly interested, although a study done in 2007 that would indicate limited effectiveness, but yet modern oncs still prescribing as first line treatment in node positive women 6 years after the publication of the study , would make me concerned about validity.
Posts.Title: need help -Taxol vered WannaCruize

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2013 11:12PM - edited Jan 22, 2013 11:15PM by luckypenny Neugirl Get whatever info you think will help you. Leave no stone unturned if that is what will satisfy you. I so remember the beginning of my dx and reading and questioning everything. I love my onc and he is really on top of things but I have to feel in control and knowledge is power. He respects my reading and research and my asking questions. Ultimately I want to know that I have done everything I could to beat this thing. Ultimately, over time my trust in the process and my providers deepens. but I have to be an active part of that process or it won't work for me. And guess what ....my dr doesn't think i am off my rocker Don't let anyone dissuade you from asking questions here or of your dr. Or providers. Many women get multiple opinions before they feel satisfied with a treatment plan. You have the luxury to do this

Posts.Content: luckypenny wrote: I had an MRI today after 2 different ultrasounds and a dx mammogram.  The radiology reports conflict , but one I most aligned to as is my breast surgeon  is the first one.. The first one is a BIRADS 4 and says area of added asymmetry in the left upper outer breast at the patients point of palpable abmormality with heterogeneous dense breast tissue.A discrete nodule is not detected, the area of added asymmetry is a change compared to the prior study.   No suspicious clustered calcifications are seen .  In the midst of dense breast tissue there are a few scattered anechoic cysts.  2nd us says birads 3 follow up in 6months- have cysts and fibroadenomas MRI today showed a slight shadow under where palpable area is, but no distinct nodules detected.  Will be having repeat US on Friday followed by core needle biopsy of suspicious area.  MRI birads 0 - inconclusive So what do you think?  What else could it be?   Can't wait till friday.  This is my seventh appt and just want an answer.     Dx 9/2011, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IIIA, Grade 2, 6/17 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Surgery 9/27/2011 Lymph node removal: Left, Right, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Left; Prophylactic mastectomy: Right Chemotherapy 10/26/2011 AC + T (Taxol) Surgery 2/13/2012 Prophylactic ovary removal Radiation Therapy 2/27/2012 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 4/1/2012 Femara (letrozole) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2013 08:24PM - edited Jan 14, 2013 08:25PM by luckypenny I agree that MRI is the gold standard.  However, I  2 ultrasounds, a diagnostic mammo and then MRI, and finally biopsy.   After the MRI, my bs was even less convinced that I had bc .  My tumor still didn't show on and imaging , not even MRI.  I had 9.5 cm area of involvement with 30% of that being dcis.    My wasn't ILC as surgeon expected, but rather IDC.  Oh and add to that 8 positive nodes out of 17.  2 of those 8 only had micromets which sort of provides me with some comfort.  I will take any hint of silver lining I can get.
